Green chemistry serves as a standardized framework for chemists, medicinal chemists, and chemical engineers to develop methods and synthetic approaches that prioritize global sustainability. It emphasizes environmentally friendly procedures, particularly catalysis, to address issues commonly encountered in conventional synthesis methods. These issues include slow reaction rates, hazardous solvents and catalysts, and prolonged reaction durations. To overcome these challenges, green chemistry advocates for the use of environmentally friendly catalysts, sustainable solvents, and innovative techniques such as microwave and ultrasonic radiation, solvent-free procedures, grinding, and chemo-mechanical methods. In particular, green chemistry supports visible-light photocatalysis, which could be used to selectively and efficiently make and change organic compounds in mild reaction conditions. Additionally, electrosynthesis has emerged as a viable alternative to traditional methods for organic molecule synthesis. Recent advancements in green chemistry have placed a significant emphasis on photocatalytic and electrochemical technologies due to their environmental benefits. This article explores how these developments have enhanced the efficient synthesis of organic compounds. By focusing on current products and techniques, this research contributes to the advancement of environmentally friendly practices in chemistry, highlighting the potential of green chemistry methods for future organic synthesis applications. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Photocatalysis Electrochemical synthesis Photoelectrochemistry Green chemistry Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Since its inception in 1991, "green chemistry" has aimed to minimize human and environmental exposure to harmful compounds by reducing or eliminating their presence. Several contemporary businesses, such as water purification, energy generation, and the production of electronics, medicines, plastics, and pesticides, employ environmentally friendly methods. Green chemistry is a discipline that aims to minimize or eliminate harmful effects on human health and the environment. It achieves this by emphasizing synthesis methods that adhere to its 12 fundamental principles. The extensive utilization of hazardous chemicals and solvents in diverse industrial procedures has bestowed significant importance upon the advancement of ecologically sustainable reactions in the field of organic chemistry. Green approaches are environmentally friendly procedures used in the field of organic chemistry. The green methods use solid-supported, bio-, fluorous, and asymmetric catalysis and synthesis to set off reactions that activate C-H bonds. Additional instances of green chemistry include the utilization of water or alternative solvents that are more environmentally friendly, such as ionic liquids, as well as the implementation of solvent-free procedures. Flow reactors, microwaves, ultrasound, and ultraviolet are all considered green technologies due to their beneficial contributions to chemistry processes. When examining environmentally-friendly approaches in the field of organic chemistry, there are two primary elements that must be taken into account. The advancements in catalyst-assisted reactions and the careful utilization of solvents are being discussed [1]. The developments of green chemistry become indispensable in the modern world; it implies the utilization of less waste, the reduction of energy utilization, and the use of environmentally benign solvents and reagents. The catalysis of green chemistry supports the critical need for waste reduction demonstrated through the balance of atom economy, the application of the 3-R rule, and the optimization of the method to ensure that the maximum number of atoms are trapped in the final formulation. Simultaneously, the reduction of energy consumption is also vital at the expense of selecting suitable solvents that are energy-efficient and less toxic, as well as conducting the process at ambient temperature. This allows process intensification or the application of continuous flow chemistry. Finally, the selection of environmentally benign solvents and reagents in catalytic settings, rather than stoichiometric, aids in waste minimization and provides efficiency and reusability [2,3]. Research into visible-light photocatalysis has increased dramatically in recent years. This increase indicates an interest in employing visible light as a reagent alongside catalysts, which bodes well for developing efficient and discriminatory chemical reactions. Previously, high-energy light sources such as ultraviolet light initiated photochemical processes by stimulating substrates or reagents. This strategy needed specialized equipment and resulted in non-specific responses that were difficult to foresee and govern. Sustainable chemical synthesis has been significantly advanced through the creation of low-energy-photon-activated photocatalysts [4]. This development has allowed for the safe and environmentally friendly use of sunlight as a chemical reagent [5]. Photocatalysis is the process of using light to accelerate specific chemical reactions. This is why it's a common practice to employ trace amounts of photocatalysts that absorb light, such as metal complexes and organic molecules [6]. For such tasks. light may be converted into chemical energy via the photocatalytic processes of energy transfer and single-electron transfer [7,8]. Over the past few decades, there has been a dramatic evolution in organic chemistry, with photoredox catalysis becoming a ubiquitous and widely applied kind of photocatalysis [9]. Visible light photoredox catalysis has proven beneficial in many synthesis and functionalization applications. It has opened the door to chemical transformations that were previously either unthinkable or extremely difficult to achieve [10,11]. Specific molecular bonds, or functional groups, are activated to achieve the desired effect. Synthetic chemists have shown that dual catalysis, which combines photocatalysis and classical catalysis, is a useful way to make chemical changes that can't be done with just one catalyst system [12]. Metallophotocatalysis is the process of combining photocatalysis with transition metal catalysis to selectively cross-couple reactions between carbon and other atoms [13,14]. This can be done in mild reaction conditions. This novel strategy has been found to impact the synthesis of small molecules significantly. Homolytic bond-breaking between carbon and hydrogen occurs during photocatalytic hydrogen atom transfer or after single electron transfer reactions [15]. Due to its feasibility, photocatalysis has risen to the forefront of synthetic chemists' toolkits. The synthesis of heterocyclic compounds and their use in medical chemistry have significantly benefited from the use of visible light photocatalysis. Examples of such uses may be found in drug development, bio-conjugation, isotopic labelling, and late-stage C-H functionalization [16]. There have been significant synthetic advances in the field of visible light photocatalysis, leading to a variety of applications in the field of drug discovery [17,18]. The gains have been incredibly tempting because of the more easygoing requirements of this method. There has been a lot of recent attention and progress in the area of visible light photocatalysis for organic transformation. This review focuses on functionalizing organic molecules via several chemical bond formation methods, which concentrate on new applications of visible light-generated photocatalytic developments. It builds upon our prior work on photocatalyzed organic synthesis [19–21]. With their scarcity of resources, overuse of fossil fuels, and widespread pollution, modern times have inspired substantial research into and use of alternative, clean energy technologies. Because of its eco-friendliness and ability to employ renewable energy sources, electro-organic synthesis is gaining importance in the chemical industry and biomedicine [22]. Electrochemical cells can modify redox potential, sparking precise reaction cascades to create valuable substances. The chemical C-N, C-C, C-S, and C-O bond synthesis are all examples of reactions that fall within this category [23,24]. Electro-organic synthesis is an alternative technique to traditional organic synthesis that uses electricity to drive chemical reactions instead of expensive and sometimes dangerous chemical oxidizing agents. Electro-organic synthesis has the benefit of being very controllable. By carefully controlling the oxidation current and voltage, it may be possible to achieve selectivity in organic processes that would otherwise be impossible to achieve using conventional synthesis methods. Electrocatalyst creation and the selective use of anodic and cathodic half-reactions are, thus, crucial areas of study. Electrochemical processes are very important for making complex compounds because they make it easier to make C-C and C-heteroatom bonds when there are no outside oxidants present. Electrochemical reactions can be broken down into three main groups: anodic oxidation processes, combined electrocatalytic activities, and cathodic reduction reactions. Oxidizing substances in stoichiometric proportions, such as hypervalent iodine species, chromium compounds, and manganese compounds, are required for conventional oxidative reactions [25]. Electrochemical oxidation techniques, on the other hand, allow for less harsh reactions involving O2 and H2O2 [26]. In their 2018 report, the members of the ACS Green Chemistry Institute Pharmaceutical Roundtable selected "alternatives for oxidations" as a crucial topic of study for green chemistry [27]. In green chemistry, using a catalyst that is recyclable through anodic oxidation is highly prized because it significantly reduces waste. In particular, electrochemical synthesis may induce oxidative cross-coupling processes [28]. There is nothing in the user's content that needs to be changed. Oxidative cross-coupling is a well-studied and proven electrochemical process involving an anodic substrate's oxidation and the reduction of protons at the cathode as part of the hydrogen evolution reaction. This review represents a unique study devoted to modern approaches to organic synthesis. In particular, its focus is on the details of electrochemical and photocatalytic synthesis with the intention of highlighting the peculiarities of methods that follow the principles of green chemistry. The former presupposes the application of electricity to enhance organic transformations with electricity also used as a clean and inexhaustible reagent. It is obvious that the approach is rather original, and on the basis of the way it may be applied, it may differ from the techniques of synthesis that are common. In its turn, the use of photocatalysis may be easily explained by the application of visible light to either mimic a clean low-cost or selective method to an organic compound. The review inquiries into the current state of these two kinds of synthesis in addition to paying attention to the relations between the two. However, in regard to the information above, it is relevant to consider not only this particular notion but also the fact that both of these methods may turn out a new synthesis that may follow green principles and resist bad reagents, solvents and environment, as well as take into account that recent programs aimed at promoting of the synthesis prove the necessity of the methods in organic chemistry. 2 Green chemistry principals Protecting human health and the natural environment through the discovery of new chemical processes, "green chemistry" aims to eliminate the initial generation of hazardous and toxic waste produced by chemical processes [29]. Fig. 1 shows the 12 principles of green chemistry. 3 General synthesis methods of green chemistry Several other physical approaches that satisfy the standards of green chemistry are under consideration nowadays. These strategies reduce pollution and shorten synthesis times without resorting to harmful solvents. Among the examples are Hydro(solvo)thermal reactions, UV irradiation, ultrasound-assisted procedures, and microwave-assisted syntheses. Synthesis with a magnetic field is one example of the less common methods addressed by these methods [30–32]. 3.1 Ball milling Using mechanical energy to drive chemical reactions, ball milling is an example of mechanochemical (tribochemical) synthesis [33,34]. It has long been a mainstay in inorganic solid-state reactions, but now it also finds widespread usage in organic chemistry. In a study, a high-energy ball mill was manufactured as an example piece of machinery [35]. In addition to improving energy efficiency, ball milling eliminates the need for potentially dangerous solvents and chemicals. These reactions, such as microwave-assisted procedures, occur at ambient temperature and without solvents. Despite having great potential, ball milling is a straightforward and environmentally friendly process that chemists rarely use. Reactions like solid oxidant/reductant oxidation/reduction, dehydrogenative coupling, polymer synthesis, amino acid/peptide synthesis, coordination compound formation, cellulose-plastic composites, and asymmetric organic reaction with catalysts can all be accomplished with a ball mill. Some processes in organic chemistry need low temperatures, and here is where mechanosynthesis comes in handy. To date, it has been put to use in a wide variety of reactions, including those involving the synthesis of imines, guanidines, oximes, (thio)s, and azides; C-C bond formation (e.g., Knoevenagel condensation; Wittig, Gewald, Michael, Reformatsky, McLurry, Glaser coupling and Suzuki; and Grignard reactions; arylaminomethylation); C-N bond formation [36]. 3.2 Microwave irradiation Organic and inorganic synthesis may benefit from this eco-friendly heating technology, which uses conduction and dipolar polarization [37]. This technology has been used to produce a wide variety of organic compounds and is prized for its low cost, high efficiency, short processing time, and little environmental impact. It has greatly aided organic synthesis and is now generally accepted as a standard approach in synthetic chemistry [38]. The molecular structure of substances is unaffected by MW energy since it is a kind of non-ionizing radiation. A material's dielectric constant establishes its microwave coupling. Thus, unlike CCl4, toluene, or aliphatic hydrocarbons, N, N-dimethylformamide, methanol, acetone, and water rapidly heat up when exposed to MW radiation. Interactions between molecules are facilitated by the transformation of electromagnetic energy into heat. Heating is achieved with little input of energy and no damage to the furnace material because of the interaction between MW irradiation and reaction components [39,40]. Therefore, conventionally heated and MW-heated samples have different temperature profiles, with the latter having higher temperatures inside and lower temperatures on the surface. All parts of the sample get the same volumetric heating. Thermal conduction inside the sample eases heat transport, reducing the energy needed. Since microwaves convert energy very efficiently into heat, the heating caused by them happens quickly and practically instantly. Simply switching off the MW devices will immediately stop it. Since various chemicals respond differently to microwave heating, MW heating is selective. This allows for targeted heating of some active regions within a sample instead of the whole sample being heated. Rapid processing, manufacture of clean goods, less heat loss, excellent heating efficiency, decreased waste, low operating expenses, and a lower risk of manufacturing undesirable byproducts are only some advantages of microwave-assisted heating over conventional heating methods. To avoid catastrophic explosions caused by the fast and uncontrolled heating of solvents, it is best to perform MW-assisted reactions under solvent-free (dry media) conditions. Microwave-transparent inorganic supports (such as montmorillonite clays, zeolites, ceramics, Al2O3, SiO2) and microwave-absorbent inorganic supports (such as graphite) may hold precursors. Some of these aids may additionally include other reagents or catalysts. Several chemical processes, including reduction, oxidation, deprotection, protection, condensation, rearrangement, and heterocyclic synthesis, have benefited from microwave-assisted reactions conducted without solvents on inorganic supports at relatively low temperatures. Hydrogen cyanide, imines, nitroalkenes, enamines, and other vital chemicals have been produced due to these reactions [41]. 3.3 Chemical synthesis using hydro(solvo)thermal conditions An acid-base solution reaction in water or organic solvents can be used to make chemicals, crystals, and polycrystals. This reaction can happen at high temperatures and pressures, usually up to 10 bar [42,43]. An autoclave, a sturdy steel cylinder with platinum, quartz, Teflon, titanium, or gold inserts, is used in the hydro(solvo)thermal process. Precursors are dissolved or suspended in the solvent (often water) within the autoclave. Over the last two decades, microwave-hydrothermal treatment' equipment has become standard in research facilities. Creating crystalline phases that are unstable at the target chemical's melting temperature is a significant benefit of the hydrothermal technique. The downside is that it calls for expensive machinery. The shape and crystallinity of the final product may be precisely controlled by adjusting the temperature, reaction time, pressure, or ratio of precursors. Because of their low environmental impact, water-based hydrothermal reactions have found widespread use in green chemistry [44]. They play an essential role in the manufacturing of several products. Reagent waste is reduced, and product yields are increased with this method. It's very helpful for making powders, films, and nanocrystals with highly tight dimensional and morphological control. One- to three-dimensional nanocrystals may be synthesized using this method with remarkable efficiency [45,46]. 3.4 Photocatalysis Photochemical reactions caused by ultraviolet light are examples of "green chemistry" processes. Organic synthesis relies on the chemical reactivity of reagents, which is affected by electrical excitation that drives these reactions. In a study of photocatalysis [47], the role of singlet oxygen in the photo-oxygenation process and how it may be used in tandem with enzyme catalysis were discussed. The possibility of improving their effectiveness using continuous flows or micro-reactors is being investigated [48]. Some examples of such reactions include the photo-catalyzed trifluoromethylation of aromatics, the formation of different F-organic compounds, and the photo-oxidation of furan derivatives, leading to the production of N-containing heterocycles [49]. The photocatalysis booth and reactors are used in these processes [50,51]. 3.5 Ultrasound-assisted synthesis Sonochemical synthesis, often known as ultrasound-assisted synthesis, is strictly a liquid-phase process since the cavitation required to work is a liquid-only phenomenon. The high temperatures of 5000 K and pressure of 1000 atm emerge from this process, which includes the creation and collapse of bubbles in a liquid. It does not, however, have any noticeable effect on the vibrational energy of chemical bonds [52]. In addition to producing free radicals and H2O2, this situation may launch or accelerate certain chemical reactions. Materials' chemical make-up, reactivity, and surface form may all be drastically altered by impacts, usually leading to a rise in effective surface area [53]. It is possible to perform ultrasound-assisted reactions in liquid systems and at the interfaces between solids and liquids and between liquids themselves. The degradation of halogenated aromatics is only one environmental activity that might benefit from reactions such as sonocatalysis. Examples of outstanding contributions in perfect harmony with the concepts of green chemistry include ultrasound-assisted organic synthesis and the manufacture of functional materials [54]. These procedures don't need a lot of power or any dangerous substances. In addition, apart from very loud ultrasonic horns [55], the prices of the necessary equipment are usually relatively modest, particularly using frequencies between 20 and 40 kHz, as in a typical ultrasonic cleaning bath. Under ultrasonic irradiation, 3-alkynyl substituted 2-chloroquinoxaline derivatives (3) were synthesized by coupling commercially available terminal alkynes (2) to 2,3-dichloroquinoxaline (1) using a Cu catalyst ( Scheme 1 ) leading to product 3 substituted with 3-alkynyl. It has been speculated that the 2-chloroquinoxaline framework might serve as a starting point for the development of compounds that specifically target COVID-19 [56]. 3.6 Magnetic fields aid synthesis Investigating magnetic field-assisted synthesis is underway as a potential substitute for existing methodologies. Several antiquated methods may produce undesirable byproducts due to the use of harmful solvents and the need for additional energy-intensive operations [57]. Magnetic fields may be used in various synthesis methods, including co-precipitation, solvothermal, and electrospinning. In addition, thin layers of specific composites may be synthesized using magnetic field methods, which can be included directly in the solution to control the growth of desired material crystals. While the simplicity of magnetic field-assisted synthesis has many advantages, it has a limited use because of its underlying principles; specifically, it can only be used on reactants and products that have magnetic characteristics. This is why magnetic iron oxides have been the subject of this related investigations [58]. Iron oxides such as Fe3O4 may change its form due to magnetism. For instance, solvothermal synthesis may produce complex nanorods [59,60]. This action is possible because the magnetic field can control metal oxide crystal formation for nanorods. Magnetic fields may be used to synthesize 250-nm Fe3O4 nanotubes during thermal breakdown. As stated, oxides synthesized with a magnetic field heat these Fe3O4 nanoparticles faster [61]. The ferromagnetic Fe3O4 nanocrystals on rGO sheets make this composite easy to produce. Due to electrostatic interactions between graphene oxide and Fe3O4 nanocrystals, the particles cluster on one reactor wall and stick together when a magnetic field is introduced. These methods may help in the development of flexible electrodes for future batteries [62]. 3.7 Green chemistry: catalysis and solvent Solvents are the primary pollutant in organic (and other) chemical processes, accounting for as much as 90% of the total. Traditional organic solvents generated from petroleum have harmful impacts on human health, the environment, and occupational safety [63]. Green media for organic synthesis need solvents that are incompatible with water, can be recycled easily, have a high boiling point, degrade quickly, non-toxic, and biodegradable. Water, polyethylene glycols, ionic liquids, and some supercritical fluids, all are well-suited for such circumstances. Glycerol, the main byproduct of biodiesel production, is an excellent solvent for environmentally friendly synthetic organic synthesis due to its non-toxic and biodegradable nature [64]. It is sometimes referred to as "organic water" by some. Due to its high polarity, Glycerol may establish hydrogen bonds and solubilize both inorganic and organic molecules. It is also low in vapor pressure, has a high boiling point, and is biodegradable as well as affordable [65]. Supercritical green solvents: Safety, nontoxicity, and little environmental effect have made supercritical carbon dioxide a go-to solvent for polymer synthesis for some time now. SC water has been used when a green solvent was preferred [66,67]. In synthesizing nanomaterials, current methods based on supercritical fluids (especially carbon dioxide or supercritical water) contribute to green chemistry (CO2- SC is utilized in producing semiconductors, for instance). Supercritical fluid technologies have been used in many processes for synthesizing materials [68]. These methods are used for many things, such as drying, cleaning, fractionation, polymerization, extraction, plating, biomass conversion, dyeing, and hydrothermal reactions [69] because of the advantages they offer in terms of recyclability and simplicity, high yields, solvent-free media, secondary pollution and absence of wastewater, etc. Ionic liquid: Green chemists often use ionic liquids, salts made of ions and ion pairs with short half-lives. They persist in a liquid state below 100 degrees Celsius or often at room temperature [70]. Catalysts: employed in organic synthesis may be either homogeneous (operating in the same phase as the liquid) or heterogeneous (operating in different phases, such as liquid/gas, solid/liquid, or solid/gas) in nature. Dry media: One of the most critical developments in green chemistry is using dry media in organic synthesis. Reagents are reacted directly or embedded in inert materials like alumina, silica, zeolites, or clays, eliminating the need for solvents [71,72]. These procedures may also make use of the aforementioned physical treatments, such as heat, ultraviolet radiation, ultrasound, and microwaves. Shorter times, lower levels of contamination, lower costs, and the capacity to scale are hallmarks of the techniques. Over the years, various review articles have been published summarizing the impressive advances in synthesizing organic compounds utilizing a greener approach. This review will focus on electrochemical and photocatalytic synthesis of organic compounds ( Fig. 2 ). This review summarizes the research progress in organic compound synthesis using photo-electrochemistry catalysts in recent years, analyzes the catalytic mechanism of various catalysts in detail, and gives a brief outlook on the research direction and development prospects in this field. 4 Electrochemical synthesis of Organic compounds 4.1 Basic principle of electrochemical synthesis Although electric current has various potential uses as a reagent in synthetic organic chemistry, many researchers are hesitant to undergo the necessary mental and physical adaptations required to utilize this approach. Nevertheless, an increasing amount of literature is endorsing the use of this technique and offering explicit instructions, demonstrating the straightforwardness of the methodology. In an electrochemical synthesis, organic molecules can undergo a chemical process in a solution and a heterogeneous process at the electrode surface, in which the LUMO of the molecule at the cathode accepts one or more electron(s) and leads to a reduction process, while the HOMO at the anode releases one or more electron(s) and leads to an oxidation process. This heterogeneous electron transfer process with the molecule leads to the formation of a reactive intermediate such as a radical cation or a radical anion. The reactive intermediates that are formed electrochemically cause subsequent chemical reactions that lead to the formation of the final products via different kinetic sequences such as electron-electron (EE), electron-chemical (EC), chemical-electron (CE), and electron-chemical-electron (ECE) [73]. An electro-organic conversion refers to a chemical reaction occurring in a liquid electrolyte system where a substrate reacts with a solid electrode. The electrodes play a crucial role in facilitating this reaction. This electrolyte system consists of a chemically inert solvent and electrolytes that aid in maintaining it, hence enhancing electrical conductivity to a satisfactory extent. A supporting electrolyte, such as a salt, acid, or base, facilitates the formation of an electrochemical double layer on the electrode's surface. This emphasizes the notion that the electrolyte and electrode system may be seen as a pair that influences the electrochemical characteristics [73,74]. Tetraalkylammonium hexafluorophosphate and tetrafluoroborate are two instances of harmless ions that exhibit exceptional solubility and have shown outstanding efficacy in many applications ( Fig. 3 ) [75,76]. Due to the potential for explosive incidents resulting from the production of organic perchlorates, it is highly advisable against using perchlorates. The applied charge quantifies the amount of reagent equivalents used, while the current density regulates the rate of the electrochemical process. Additionally, temperature is a crucial factor that significantly influences electrolysis [77]. 4.2 Electrochemical Catalysis by Nobel-Transition Metals In recent years, the electrochemical synthesis of organic compounds has gained significant attention due to its potential as a greener approach compared to traditional chemical methods. One noteworthy aspect of this advancement is the application of electrochemical catalysis by transition metals, which has shown impressive promise in facilitating efficient and selective organic synthesis [78]. Recent research has shown remarkable progress in using transition-metal complexes as mediators and catalysts in electrochemical processes [79–83]. Because it may be utilized instead of stoichiometric oxidants in a broad range of X-H bond-functionalization procedures, the cathodic hydrogen evolution reaction is advantageous for electrochemical reactions. The integration of the hydrogen evolution process with transition-metal catalysis is a formidable task. Although the standard reduction potentials of various transition metals vary, the ions of active metals like manganese, iron, nickel, and cobalt are comparatively resistant to cathodic reduction [84,85]. This characteristic makes them suitable for catalytic cycles, including the hydrogen evolution reaction. Significant progress has been achieved in catalyzing HER-coupled electrochemical reactions using Ni, Mn, Fe, and Co molecules. The literature has recently discussed these reactions, emphasizing electrochemical C-H functionalization procedures [86–88]. Researchers have effectively established MnBr2 as a catalyst for the alkene's electrochemical diazidation without the need for a ligand [E2+/0 = 1.17 V against a normal hydrogen electrode ( Scheme 2 ) [89]. The noble metal salts include the compounds of rhodium, silver, ruthenium, rhenium, osmium, palladium, iridium, gold, and platinum, which have low standard reduction potentials and are hence more likely to be reduced than protonic species [90]. Reactions may be conveniently performed in a compartmented cell, preventing accidental contact between the cathode and metal. However, production costs and mass transfer rates increase when a split cell is used. It would be most efficient to conduct electrochemical operations catalyzed by these metals in a single cell. Here are the latest implementations of Ru, Ir, Rh, Pd, Cu, and Au catalysts in advancing electrochemical processes in undivided cells, focusing on enhancing their stability. Excellent conversion yields for products were reported by researchers regarding the Cu-catalyzed electrochemical dehydrogenative cross-coupling reactions; they include the coupling of aromatic Csp2-H bonds from substrates with secondary amines, as shown in Scheme 3 a [91]. A partitioned cell was selected because Cu species are often depleted near the cathode. Mei's group used the iodide to catalyze a low-anodic-potential Cu3+/Cu+/Cu+ cycle. In 2019, a study was published by Kathiravan and coworkers outlining a method for electrochemically catalyzing the amination of C-H bonds using copper. As shown in Scheme 3 b, this method used the quinoline structure as a chelating group. The process of alkyne annulation via the C-H alkynylation pathway was also sped up with the help of a copper catalyst and a directing group (Scheme 3 b) [92]. The discovery of Cu-catalyzed electrochemical B-H oxygenation processes of O-carboranes represents a significant advance in the field. They performed the reactions under standard laboratory conditions using an 8-aminoquinoline as a standard (Scheme 3 c) [93]. Batch type cells are often used for small-scale studies and for developing synthetic approaches in their early stages [140]. In separate operations, H-cells are used, but in undivided operations, conventional "beaker cells" are used. When you need to prepare small amounts of material, a batch cell is an easy and practical option that requires little configuration. However, they aren't very good at producing large amounts of compounds; in fact, they seldom produce more than tens of grams [141]. The modest ratio of electrode surface area to reactor volume (A/V) is the main scaling constraint of batch cells. As the reactor size increases during a scale-up effort, the volumetric flow rate (A/V) drops dramatically. Because efficiency is strongly related to the A/V ratio, batch electrolytic processes become less efficient with increasing cell size. Slow mass transfer is one potential drawback of batch cells, although this is very technique-dependent [142]. The method for scaling up electrochemical operations has been around for a long time. Using parallel plate flow cells is the deciding factor . Planar electrodes set in parallel to each other form the basis of a parallel plate reactor. Extremely high A/V ratios are the consequence of the extremely small spacing between the electrodes, which is often less than 1 mm. In low volume batch cells, the ratio of electrode surface area to cell volume is often less than 1, even though it is 10 when the interelectrode gap is 1 mm [143]. The reaction mixture is passed across the gap between the electrodes in a parallel plate reactor during electrolysis, with the proper current density applied using the right power source. Most importantly, the size of a parallel plate reactor may be readily changed. As long as the spacing between the electrodes is constant, the A/V ratio remains constant regardless of the size of the electrodes. The integer eight. Another easy way to scale up is to arrange numerous pairs of electrodes in a way called numbering up. This is in addition to increasing the size of the electrodes [144]. Despite their widespread usage for electrochemical process scaling, parallel plate flow electrolysis cells have a number of drawbacks. To avoid clogging the cell's small channels, it is crucial to ensure that the reaction mixture does not include any particles, as is the case with many flow-based reactor systems. Because it may need diluted circumstances to fully dissolve solid components, preventing solids in a reaction mixture may affect the process's sustainability. In addition, the solubility of the reagents must be considered when selecting solvents for a reaction to be carried out in a parallel plate cell so that consistent conditions may be achieved. Cost, environmental friendliness, and efficacy need not be the only considerations in this selection [145]. The counter electrode is a source of gas in many electrochemical reactions. Hydrogen gas is a common consequence of anodic oxidation processes [146], which involve reducing a proton source at the cathode. One major issue with single pass processing is gas evolution, which results in a significant volume of gas relative to the liquid phase. As a result, the reactor's effective volume and the electrode's contact area with the reaction mixture are both reduced. The processing flow rate, or the speed of the liquid phase relative to the electrode surface, determines how efficient mass transfer is. Recirculation mode (semibatch) processing of reaction mixtures benefits from high flow rates for this reason [147]. While operating in single-pass processing, sometimes called continuous mode, slower speeds are required to guarantee the reaction mixture is converted optimally before it exits the reactor. The cell's mass transport properties are subsequently compromised. 5 Photocatalytic synthesis of organic compounds 5.1 Principal of photocatalytic synthesis The ability of light to activate substrates, reagents, or catalytic intermediates under gentle circumstances makes it a very effective chemical reaction reagent. Historically, photochemical techniques have used ultraviolet light to stimulate substrates. These light sources are very concentrated and need specialized equipment. They often generate unexpected and indiscriminate responses. Photocatalysts triggered by low-energy photons facilitate environmentally sustainable chemical synthesis by using non-toxic visible light [148]. Photocatalysts may initiate transformations via many mechanisms, as seen in Fig. 4 A. Visible light photoredox catalysis is an effective method for organic synthesis [149]. Excited catalysts (PC∗) may undergo either oxidative or reductive quenching cycles when exposed to radiation, depending on the substrates and reagents present. This is because they can either accept or contribute one electron. A catalyst in an excited state transforms an electron acceptor (A) into a powerful oxidant (PC•+) by oxidative quenching. A suitable donor (D) may provide an electron to the oxidized catalyst, completing the catalytic cycle. Under certain reaction conditions, inverse reactions may take place to fully complete a reductive quenching cycle. Redox processes may also include proton-coupled electron transfer (PCET) [150]. Photocatalytic hydrogen atom transfer (HAT) occurs when the photocatalyst breaks C-H bonds by homolytic cleavage or following a single electron transfer (SET) process. Photocatalysts (PCs) may induce chemical reactions by transferring energy from an excited state to a substrate or reagent that is unable to absorb light of the required wavelength [151]. The integration of photocatalysis with "conventional" catalysis enables the execution of reactions that would otherwise be unattainable using a single catalyst. The process is shown in Fig. 4 B. Metallaphotocatalysis, a technique that merges photocatalysis with transition metal catalysis, enables controlled cross-coupling reactions between carbon and heteroatoms as well as carbon and carbon [152]. Success relies on the use of SET mechanisms, the incorporation of radical additions, or the regulation of the oxidation states of transition metal complexes by photosensitization. The combination of photo- and organocatalysis allows for the selective addition of functional groups to aldehydes by exploiting excited photocatalysts and enamine intermediates. The authors performed extensive epimerization studies to shed light on the substantial diastereoselectivity obtained in the resultant compounds. This method exhibits a high tolerance for a variety of functional groups and is capable of efficiently generating the targeted products with high yields and diastereoselectivity [171]. 5.4.5 The 1,3-dicarbonyl Minisci reaction A research group recently gave a captivating demonstration of a three-component C-H heteroarylation by minuscule reagents. In this approach, a combination of exposing [Ir(ppy)2(dtbbpy)](PF6) to light, a 1,3-dicarbonyl molecule may be converted into vinyl ether and heteroarene ( Scheme 22 ). The reaction mechanism involves photochemical oxidation to produce an electrophilic 1,3-dicarbonyl radical. After interacting with an electron-rich vinyl ether, this radical undergoes a transition in its chemical behaviour, leading to the creation of a nucleophilic radical. To get the required product, the radical couples with protonated heteroarene. The formation of adducts between electron-rich olefins and 1,3-dicarbonyl radicals is essential to the success of this approach. Without it, the reaction might form a dimerization product due to the polar character of the 1,3-dicarbonyl radical. This reaction is very flexible since it works with a large variety of quinoline/isoquinoline derivatives and 1,3-dicarbonyl molecule derivatives. Mechanistically, the reaction can only proceed with electron-rich olefins; hence, only those will provide the desired results [172]. 5.4.6 N-heteroaryl sulfone desulfonation by photoredox alkylation Researchers have developed a technique to selectively add alkyl groups to N-heteroaryl sulfones without the need for acid or oxidizing agents. To do this, radicals are produced from alkylsilicates and the photoredox process is catalyzed by [Ru(bpy)3](PF6)2. Researchers found that the yields for different substitution patterns using a variety of substrates were less than ideal, despite the promise of diversified heteroaryl sulfones. A more reliable precursor known as alkyl 1,4-dihydropyridines was used to get around this problem. Combining this option with the organophotocatalyst 4CzIPN increased its efficiency ( Scheme 23 ). This method demonstrated high tolerance towards several functional groups, including chlorinated substrates, and allowed for the efficient oxidant-free alkylation of sulfones. It's important to note that 4CzIPN coupled with alkyl silicate, another radical precursor, did not provide satisfactory results [173]. 5.4.7 Enamide alkylation of N-hydroxyphthalimide esters in a stereoselective manner Photocatalyzed decarboxylative cross-coupling is a method invented by researchers to create C-C bonds. The method makes an ester of N-hydroxyphthalimide from enamide. By catalyzing the reaction using the photoredox catalyst [Ir(ppy)3], a very efficient approach is provided for the synthesizing enamide with a -C(sp2)-H group stereospecifically. Several NHP esters derived from naturally occurring amino acids are shown to be tolerated in this process. It reliably produces good to excellent results across the board [174]. The suggested process entails the transfer of one electron from the excited state photocatalyst [Ir(ppy)3]* to NHP ester, forming a radical anion. This radical anion then undergoes decarboxylation, leading to the production of alkyl radical. The enamide reacts with alkyl radicals, resulting in the formation of a radical intermediate. Subsequently, intermediate C undergoes a single electron transfer in which the cation intermediate is formed from [Ir(ppy)3]+. There is a balance between the cation intermediate and the iminium ion. The required functionalized enamide is produced by deprotonating these species, which originate from the more stable conformer 1. 5.4.8 Interrupted Pummerer activation permits the classical C-H/C-H coupling of arenes Biaryls are excellent candidates for use in engineering and medicine. Recently, researchers reported a fascinating explanation for a single-pot, metal-free aryl-aryl cross-coupling reaction. When the organophotocatalyst 10-phenyl phenothiazine is used in conjunction with heterocyclic radical traps, the scientists were able to cross-couple non-prefunctionalized arene. Dibenzothiophene-S-oxide is a mediator in an interrupted Pummerer activation process that preferentially activates arene. In the presence of PTH, this activated arene subsequently undergoes cross-coupling with a radical trap ( Scheme 24 a). Compared to using aryl halides and aryl diazonium salts for aryl couplings [175], this technology is better in three areas: it is easier to use, it is safer, and it is more stable. The aryldibenzothiophenium salt A is formed via an interrupted Pummerer activation of the nucleophilic arene with sulfoxide, which then undergoes a single electron transfer with the excited state photocatalyst PTH* to create the aryl radical B while eliminating the dibenzothiophene. Radical trapping of the aryl radical B then produces the coupled intermediate C, which is then oxidized to the coupled intermediate D and then aromatized to produce the coupled product ( Scheme 24 b). A 67% yield of the target cross-coupled product was achieved by following this approach, the arene was tert-butylbenzene, the photocatalyst was PTH, the radical trap was N-methylpyrrole, and the activator was DBTSO ( Scheme 24 c) [175].. 5.5 Formation of C-H bonds 5.5.1 Trifluoromethylarene hydrodefluorination To produce defluorinated derivatives ( Scheme 25 ), researchers have proposed a straightforward and efficient photocatalyzed process for the precise removal of fluorine atoms from trifluoromethylarenes. For this method to work, a hydrogen atom donor known as 4-hydroxythiophenol was used to replace a single fluorine atom. The reaction occurred in the presence of a compound called 2,4,5,6-tetrakis(diphenylamino)isophthalonitrile, an organophotocatalyst. A mixture of 1,2,2,6,6-pentamethylpiperidine and 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine in 1,2-dichloroethane was employed as the base in this procedure. This method's adaptability makes it a viable option for reducing fluorine atoms in various drug molecules [176]. The researchers offer a mechanism that might explain the response based on several studies. Starting with 4-HTP, a thiolate A is formed, which reacts with a photocatalyst in an excited state to undergo reductive quenching, yielding a thiyl radical intermediate B. In this step, trifluoromethylarene oxidizes the reduced photocatalyst to produce the radical anion. After undergoing mesolytic cleavage of fluoride, this radical anion becomes difluorobenzylic radical. 5.5.2 Hydrogenation of heteroaromatic olefins Researchers recorded a significant instance of the use of photoredox catalysts to enable enzymes that catalyze the asymmetric hydrogenation of heteroaromatic olefins by using flavin-dependent ‘ene’ reductases. Researchers obtained 'ene' reductase from N. punctiforme and utilized it with the photocatalyst [Ru(bpy)3]Cl2 to hydrolyze vinyl-2-pyridine. The process was successful in producing a hydrogenated product with above-average efficiency. A C-centered radical anion is formed during the reaction as a consequence of Ru(bpy)31+ reducing vinyl-2-pyridine. This radical anion may quickly become a neutral radical by being protonated. Finally, a hydrogen atom transfer results in the formation of the hydrogenated derivative ( Scheme 26 ) [177]. 5.6 P-Halogenanisole dehalogenation Researchers provided a notable example of Flavin photocatalysis for synthesizing C-H bonds [178]. The proposed method for dehalogenation p-halogenanisoles uses deazaflavin as the photocatalyst, diisopropyl(ethyl)amine as the sacrificial reducing agent, and cesium carbonate as the base. 5.7 Scalability of Photocatalytic organic synthesis Photocatalysis is a type of artificial photosynthesis that uses environmentally beneficial, cost-effective, and long-lasting materials to address energy and environmental issues. Nevertheless, experts in both academia and industry need to pay attention to photocatalysis since it faces certain challenges. At first, other laboratories may find it difficult to use the developed approaches due to issues with repeatability in the published photocatalytic processes. The use of heat or cold is a common component of "conventional" reactions, which may be readily reproduced in other labs. There is a strong relationship between the experimental setup and the reproducibility of photocatalytic processes. The usage of light-emitting diode (LED) lights, which may have different photon outputs and emission spectra, is common in light-mediated processes. These factors could have a major effect on how a photochemical reaction turns out. The most effective method for standardizing photochemical reactors is to use specialized, commercially accessible equipment [179]. But since handmade installations are so cheap, it's quite unlikely that it will happen. A researcher from AbbVie, GSK, Pfizer, and Merck made an insightful remark about issues with photochemical setups. They stressed that experimental methods should include detailed descriptions of the light sources and reactor configurations [180]. Also, the reaction mixture has to be exposed to light effectively for photocatalytic reactions to occur. When exposed to incoming light, solvents, starting materials, products, photosensitizers, and PCs may all serve as filters, reducing the intensity of light for the other components of the reaction mixture. At bigger scales, the Beer-Lambert equation describing photon transit attenuation presents formidable obstacles. The connection between a molecule's absorption (A), its molar extinction coefficient (ε), concentration (c), and the optical path length of the light (l) is described by Equation, which is also known as the Beer-Lambert equation. (1) A = ∈ C l Particularly when scaling a photoreaction in a batch process, the trade-off has substantial ramifications. The optimal method for overcoming this limitation is to use continuous flow microreactors [181,182]. The whole reaction mixture may be uniformly exposed to radiation in flow reactors due to their small size. This allows photochemical processes to be scaled up and run much faster than in batch reactors. Reactions with multiple steps are best handled by flow chemistry. Highly effective mass transfer between two or even three phases is made possible by the small size of the reactor, which leads to high surface-area-to-volume ratios. The mass-flow controllers allow flow reactors to manage the stoichiometry of gaseous reagents, which is a benefit. The solubility of gases in the reaction mixture is enhanced since these reactors may be easily pressurized [183]. 6 Conclusion and Future Aspects The contemporary period of photocatalysis has led to numerous innovative changes and has emerged as a potent synthetic approach. As the field develops and the equipment becomes more uniform and easily obtainable, the ability to reproduce results between different sites will improve, and the range of chemicals that can be studied will grow. Further comprehensive mechanistic investigations are necessary to provide a clearer understanding of response mechanisms. Frequently, mechanisms are proposed without adequate empirical substantiation. In order to make additional progress in terms of new activation modes and synergies in cooperative-mode catalysis, it is crucial to have a thorough understanding of the reactivity of the excited states of the photocatalyst and substrates, as well as the interaction between the two. Photocatalysis is expected to have a promising future and is predicted to become a widely used reaction method in the 21st century, similar to how transition metal catalysis greatly impacted synthetic advancements in the 20th century.In order to commercialize heterogeneous electrocatalysis, it is necessary to find cost-effective methods for producing stable electrocatalysts that are abundant in the earth's resources. Nickel (Ni), Cobalt (Co), and Iron (Fe) are examples of non-noble transition elements that have the ability to serve as electrocatalysts in two different ways. Nevertheless, there is still room for improvement in terms of the activity and selectivity. The gradual degradation of the catalysts under these severe circumstances is harmful to the stability of the catalyst. When using highly concentrated alkali solutions, cathodic and anodic processes help to reduce the loss of ions and make it easier for oxidation and reduction to occur. Hence, it is imperative to investigate electrocatalysts that are abundant on Earth due to their exceptional catalytic efficiency and durability throughout a broad pH spectrum. The paper provides an overview of the latest advancements in the use of visible light-mediated photocatalysis for the synthesis of organic molecules, with a focus on its practical applications. This overview has examined the photophysical and electrochemical properties, as well as the redox potentials, of several widely used photocatalysts, such as TiO2, for the purpose of visible light utilization. Visible light photocatalysis enables a wide range of chemical reactions, including the creation of C-C, C-N, C-O, C-H, C-S/Se, C-P, and C-halogen bonds. Photocatalytic methods utilize visible light as a precise energy source to focus it towards the photocatalyst, enabling reactions to occur at or below room temperature. Visible light photocatalysis has substantially benefited several classes of chemical processes, with a special emphasis on synergistic interactions. Visible light photocatalysis is a relatively new technique in the pharmaceutical sector, but it has significant potential. This approach has led to a substantial transformation in drug discovery and the production of very powerful organic molecules with medicinal applications. The potential for electrochemical conversion of inexpensive organic molecules into valuable products through oxidation and reduction processes is growing because to the declining costs of renewable power and natural gas. The flexibility and versatility of electrochemical conversion over a wide range of temperatures and pressures offer substantial advantages compared to standard organic synthesis approaches. Due to its versatility, a diverse array of products can be manufactured in a decentralized manner with minimal inefficiency. Regrettably, there has been insufficient allocation of resources towards research in this crucial field, resulting in the technology being at an early stage of development and some years away from being widely implemented for commercial use. This article provides a summary of the latest advancements in the utilization of heterogeneous catalysts in electrochemical reduction and oxidation processes. Additionally, it offers a concise examination of the pertinent technological and economic factors. Electro-organic reduction/oxidation is a more precise term to describe the process, as it offers greater thermodynamic benefits and results in a more valuable final product. Nevertheless, certain challenges need to be addressed, such as a limited comprehension of cathodic and anodic mechanisms, as well as issues related to effectiveness, mediator separation, product selectivity, stability, and isolation. In order to facilitate commercialization, future research on electro-organic synthesis should prioritize the following crucial attributes. To successfully commercialize heterogeneous electrocatalysis, it is crucial to develop cost-effective and durable electrocatalysts using naturally existing components. Transition elements such as nickel, iron, and cobalt, which are not considered noble, have the ability to act as bifunctional electrocatalysts. Although there has been significant progress in terms of activity and selectivity, there is still room for further improvement. The stability of a catalyst is undermined by the conditions that lead to its gradual degradation. The utilization of highly concentrated alkaline solutions induces cathodic and anodic reactions, which reduce the loss of ions and promote oxidation and reduction processes. Naturally occurring electrocatalysts on Earth are intriguing due to their exceptional catalytic effectiveness and enduring stability across a broad spectrum of pH levels. Current studies on anodic oxidation processes have mostly concentrated on three specific domains: the oxidation of alcohols, ammonia, and urea; the decomposition of biomass; and the joint oxidation of these substances. Nevertheless, there remains a considerable distance to cover before hydrogen generated from alcohol oxidation combined with HER or eCO2RR can rival hydrogen produced from petroleum. The separation and purification of as-synthesized compounds from electrolytes necessitate the use of intricate techniques and costly procedures. Optimizing the reaction conditions to provide absolute product selectivity and purification is crucial for the successful commercialization of sophisticated alcohol oxidation technology. CH's electrochemical activation enables the production of oxygenated platform molecules from hydrocarbon feedstock. Operative approaches are essential for comprehending the modifications occurring on the catalytic surfaces of the cathode and anode, as well as the electrochemical oxidation process. Multiple highly promising electro-organic conversions are currently progressing rapidly. A curriculum vitae (CV) is frequently necessary to authenticate the proposed mechanism. Upon thorough examination of electro-organic synthesis from various perspectives, it becomes evident that this technology holds great promise and has resulted in multiple significant breakthroughs. Nevertheless, it possesses untapped possibilities that can be used to drive its growth. Over the coming years, the utilization of variable and plentiful power will have a significant influence on chemical processes, enabling the production of chemicals with greater value. In order to achieve sustainable chemistry, organic chemical synthesis must surmount a multitude of challenges. coredata.dc:description: Green chemistry serves as a standardized framework for chemists, medicinal chemists, and chemical engineers to develop methods and synthetic approaches that prioritize global sustainability. It emphasizes environmentally friendly procedures, particularly catalysis, to address issues commonly encountered in conventional synthesis methods. These issues include slow reaction rates, hazardous solvents and catalysts, and prolonged reaction durations. To overcome these challenges, green chemistry advocates for the use of environmentally friendly catalysts, sustainable solvents, and innovative techniques such as microwave and ultrasonic radiation, solvent-free procedures, grinding, and chemo-mechanical methods. In particular, green chemistry supports visible-light photocatalysis, which could be used to selectively and efficiently make and change organic compounds in mild reaction conditions. Additionally, electrosynthesis has emerged as a viable alternative to traditional methods for organic molecule synthesis. Recent advancements in green chemistry have placed a significant emphasis on photocatalytic and electrochemical technologies due to their environmental benefits. This article explores how these developments have enhanced the efficient synthesis of organic compounds. By focusing on current products and techniques, this research contributes to the advancement of environmentally friendly practices in chemistry, highlighting the potential of green chemistry methods for future organic synthesis applications.
coredata.dc:title: Electrochemical and Photocatalytic Synthesis of Organic Compounds Utilizing a Greener Approach. A review
